title: late 15th century english font
content:
Hello, there!  
I am trying to ID the particular font that was (handwritten by two different scribes) on the original Winchester Manuscript of Malory’s Arthurian Legends. Like I said, late 15th century england. I am not even remotely knowledgable on the subject of fonts, but this is partly why I recently joined - I would like to know what this general type is considered.  
Thanks!  
Here are a couple of pics:

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [malory035.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20081002010051/http:/typophile.com/files/malory035.jpg) | 585.56 KB |
| [malory045-scriptb.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20081002010051/http:/typophile.com/files/malory045-scriptb.jpg) | 603.82 KB |

 [‹ Font ID - Beautiful Modernist face](http://web.archive.org/web/20081002010051/http:/typophile.com/node/49675 "Go to previous forum topic") [Landmark Theaters Typeface ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081002010051/http:/typophile.com/node/49868 "Go to next forum topic")
author: molly_rose

comments.content:
Although it’s not type or a font, I believe this is an example of Bastarda. I’m not really an expert on hand-written styles, so let’s see what the others say.

- Lex

Yep. One of the very few quality renditions of that style: [St Augustin Civilité](http://web.archive.org/web/20081002010051/http:/www.typography.com/fonts/font_styles.php?productLineID=100012) (part of H&FJ’s Historical Allsorts).  
Another – brandnew – one: [Givry](http://web.archive.org/web/20081002010051/http:/www.type-together.com/ampl_font.php?idpuente=18) by Tom Grace.

Funny, a quite similar request at typografie.info (a german forum)  
 [http://www.typografie.info/typoforum/viewtopic.php?f=35&t=5861](http://web.archive.org/web/20081002010051/http:/www.typografie.info/typoforum/viewtopic.php?f=35&t=5861 "http://www.typografie.info/typoforum/viewtopic.php?f=35&t=5861")  
scroll down the thread for links and pictures

Some links from there
